user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of deinit_data:
```c
static void
deinit_data (void)
{
  if (NULL != resp_single)
    MHD_destroy_response (resp_single);
  resp_single = NULL;
  if (NULL != resps)
  {
    unsigned int i;
    for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)
      MHD_destroy_response (resps[i]);
    num_resps = 0;
    free (resps);
  }
  resps = NULL;
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
  body_dyn = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function deinit_data:
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_destroy_response (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == response)
    return;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (0 != --(response->reference_count))
  {
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
    return;
  }
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
  MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (NULL != response->crfc)
    response->crfc (response->crc_cls);

  if (NULL != response->data_iov)
  {
    free (response->data_iov);
  }

  while (NULL != response->first_header)
  {
    pos = response->first_header;
    response->first_header = pos->next;
    free (pos->header);
    free (pos->value);
    free (pos);
  }
  free (response);
}
...
static struct MHD_Response *resp_single = NULL
...
static struct MHD_Response **resps = NULL
...
static unsigned int num_resps = 0
...
static char *body_dyn = NULL
...
struct MHD_Response
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided code fragments (deinit_data, MHD_destroy_response, and the related variable declarations). There are no calls to memcmp (nor any apparent string-comparison logic using memcmp) in the shown code. The fragments only perform NULL checks, resource destruction, and free operations; they do not compare null-terminated strings with memcmp. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. (Note: a memcmp use could exist elsewhere or inside callbacks such as response->crfc, but those definitions are not provided here and thus cannot be flagged from the given code.)
